newsArray.title: J-Mac earns more cash than Zac during Hong Kong stint
newsArray.description: James McDonald has beaten Zac Purton at his own game.
newsArray.content: Horse Racing Don't miss out on the headlines from Horse Racing. Followed categories will be added to My News. James McDonald has beaten Zac Purton at his own game. In October 2022, Purton famously told J-Mac he was ‚Äústupid‚Äù for staying in Australia and not chasing the riches on offer in Hong Kong. ‚ÄúAt the end of the day when he looks at his bank account and he looks at my bank account, he‚Äôs stupid for staying in Australia,‚Äù Purton told SEN. ‚Ä¢ ‚ÄòWe are humans, my heart bleeds‚Äô: Williams extends hand to Khawaja ‚ÄúHe can stay (in Australia), win all the trophies, get all the accolades, and at the end of his career he‚Äôll still have a mortgage on his home. It‚Äôs as simple as that. Financially it just doesn‚Äôt make sense. ‚ÄúYou can make six to seven times comfortably (in Hong Kong) what he would make a year.‚Äù Well, McDonald has just had a taste of that life, completing a 37-day stint in the Asian racing mecca and pocketing more cash than the six-time Hong Kong champion over the same period. In Hong Kong, a jockey gets 10 per cent of the prizemoney for winning and 5 per cent for finishing second to sixth. McDonald‚Äôs 15 winners earned $HK35,296,800, meaning he trousered a total of $HK3,529,680 ($A664,137), the bulk of which came from Romantic Warrior ‚Äôs brave victory in the Group 1 Hong Kong Cup. Wunderbar caps a J-Mac treble! The star rider returns a three-timer on the final day of his short-term contract... √∞¬ü¬î¬• @mcacajamez #LuckyStart | #HKracing pic.twitter.com/awPyARiFiX ‚Äî HKJC Racing (@HKJC_Racing) January 1, 2024 In that same period, Purton had 19 winners ($HK29,439,600) but only snared himself $HK2,943,960 ($A553,883) because they were in lesser quality races. His Group 1 victory, the Hong Kong Sprint with Lucky Sweynesse , was worth significantly less than the Cup while 12 of the 19 came in Class Four or Class Five. In contrast, 11 of McDonald‚Äôs 15 successes came in Class Three or above. ‚Ä¢ Triumph, scandal and tragedy ‚Äì the moments that shaped 2023 Across 12 meetings from November 26 to January 1, McDonald collected a grand total of $HK50,398,695 in prizemoney, his share a very healthy $HK4,284,774.75 ($A806,140). For the season so far, that $HK50,398,695 number is second only to Purton ($HK92,120,285) and ahead of the likes of Karis Teetan ($HK50,136,960), Vincent Ho ($HK49,963,165) and Hugh Bowman ($HK25,953,550). Not bad for 5¬Ω weeks‚Äô work ‚Äì J-Mac certainly knows what Purton was talking about now. But Purton, as usual, will end up having the last laugh given the maximum tax rate in Hong Kong is 15 per cent while the Australian Taxation Office will take a much bigger bite out of McDonald‚Äôs earnings. Originally published as James McDonald earned more cash than Zac Purton during his Hong Kong stint Join the conversation Add your comment to this story To join the conversation, please log in. newsArray.title: New Test opener need not be a specialist: Cummins
creator: Scott Bailey
newsArray.description: Australia captain Pat Cummins has said he would have no objection to Australia opting against a specialist opener to replace David Warner.
newsArray.content: Captain Pat Cummins would have no issue with the selectors opting against a specialist opener to replace David Warner in Australia's Test team, indicating picking the best batsman should be a priority. Warner's rollercoaster 112-Test career will come to an end at the SCG this week, with the veteran opener fulfilling his dream of a home farewell when Australia play Pakistan in the third Test. But amid the celebrations for Warner this week in a series that is already won, the biggest question that looms is who will replace him against West Indies in Adelaide on January 17. Marcus Harris, Cameron Bancroft and Matt Renshaw remain the front-runners out of the specialist openers, but Australia are open to going outside that group. Coach Andrew McDonald left the door open earlier this week for Cameron Green to take on the job, if it allowed Australia to pick their best six batsmen. Another option would be to shift Travis Head, Marnus Labuschage or Mitch Marsh to the top, allowing Green to return to the side. The likes of Ricky Ponting and Justin Langer have each warned against such a move, while Bancroft has also voiced a case for a specialist to be selected. But Cummins said he would be open to a move from a regular middle-order batsman. "Uzzy (Usman Khawaja) wasn't a specialist (opener) until it was basically the only spot available in the team and he forced his way in," Cummins, who has been involved in informal discussions on the looming selection, said. "Ideally, you've got someone who's had experience opening, but I don't think it's a blanket rule." Cummins has some first-hand experience on the topic, as a Test quick who has taken the new ball against specialist openers and those filling in the role in opposition teams. "I think every case is different," Cummins said. "If someone's been picked in the side as an opener, but their record's not great, you feel probably feel more of a chance (to get their wicket), rather than if you're picking their best batter. "I don't think it's a big deal. It's just a batting position, everyone chops and changes around a little bit." Cummins on Tuesday lauded Warner as Australia's best-ever three-format batter, and noted his absence will be felt as much off the field as on it. The 37-year-old will play in this year's T20 World Cup, and while he has retired from ODI cricket, Warner is open to a comeback in major 50-over tournaments if asked. Australia's captain indicated that would likely not be required, but was not wholly opposed to the idea of an uncontracted Warner returning. "It's probably time to give some others a crack," Cummins said. "But knowing he is still going to be playing cricket, it might be more of a break-glass-in-case-of-emergency option. "He's going to be scoring runs somewhere in the world, so you never know." Warner's retirement is the first from within the Test team since Mitchell Johnson's in late 2015. But many more loom in coming years with Labuschagne the only player from an unchanged XI for the Sydney Test aged under 30. Cummins is confident, however, the vast majority of the team will be able to face India next summer. "Realistically there is going to be some rate of change," Cummins said. "We probably thought it was going to happen a little bit sooner but everyone is hanging on. "After this block of Test matches, we don't play again until next summer. So I don't see anything in the immediate future that is going to change."

newsArray.title: India Women vs Australia Women Free Live Streaming Online, 3rd ODI 2023-24: Watch Live Telecast of IND-W vs AUS-W Cricket Match on TV With Time in IST
newsArray.description: The hosts are trailing 0-2 and a whitewash is on the cards, should they fail to improve their levels. If batting was their strong point in the opening match, it let them down in the second game as they failed to chase down 256.
newsArray.content: India Women will clash with Australia Women in the third match of the three-game ODI series on Tuesday, January 2. The IND-W vs AUS-W 3rd ODI 2023-24 match will be played at the Wankhede Stadium in Mumbai and it will start at 01:30 pm IST (Indian Standard Time). Sports18 Network is the official broadcaster of Indian cricket and will provide the live telecast of the India Women vs Australia Women ODI series as well. The IND-W vs AUS-W 3rd ODI live telecast will be available on Sports18 1 and HD TV channel. For live streaming details of IND-W vs AUS-W, scroll below. With Sports18 holding the broadcast rights, JioCinema will provide free live streaming of the IND-W vs AUS-W ODI series online. Fans can access the JioCinema mobile app or website to watch free live streaming of IND-W vs AUS-W 3rd ODI online.

newsArray.title: Records are meant to be broken: McGrath backs Lyon to top all-time Australia list
newsArray.description: Records are meant to be broken: McGrath backs Lyon to top all-time Australia list
newsArray.content: Listen to Story Legendary Australia fast bowler Glenn McGrath backed off-spinner Nathan Lyon to continue going on a record-breaking spree. to get to 500 Test wickets. The veteran off-spinner achieved the feat during the first Test of the ongoing 3-match series against Pakistan in Perth in December 2023. Glenn McGrath, who will be in Sydney for the Pink Test from January 3, said he was confident that Nathan Lyon would go past his Test tally and he has no problems being overtaken by the veteran off-spinner. Lyon is in the third spot in Australia's all-time Test list with 505 wickets in 124 matches. McGrath had finished his career with 563 wickets in 124 Tests while the late Shane Warne had 708 Test wickets in 145 Tests. Lyon, 36, has shown no signs of slowing down and has been an integral member of the Australian Test side, both overseas and at home. Lyon's ability to trouble opposition batters with his off-spin on pitches in Australia that are not conducive for spin bowling has set him apart from the rest. ‚ÄúTo me, records are there for people to break. If Lyono goes past (me), credit to him. He‚Äôs had an incredible career. I wish him all the best, I hope he goes past me. That‚Äôs what it‚Äôs about," McGrath said in Sydney as his foundation was preparing for the Pink Test, aimed at raising awareness about Breast Cancer and fundraising. "I will still be the most wickets by a fast bowler, so at least I have got something up my sleeve," he added. The former Australian fast bowler did not rule out Nathan Lyon's chances of going past Shane Warn√©'s tally, saying it would be completely up to the off-spinner to decide if he wanted to give that shot. Whether he gets to ‚ÄòShano‚Äô, that might be a different kettle of fish. It is up to him. He is obviously bowling well, he knows the game so well. It is totally up to him," McGrath added. Lyon flaunted his commitment and passion for the game when he made an incredible recovery from a calf injury tha sidelined him for the second-half of the 2023 season. Lyon underwent a rigorous 13-week rehabilitation program to get fit in time for the series against Pakistan. Lyon has often spoken about his desire to prolong his career. After getting to 500, Lyon stressed the importance of not taking anything for granted and putting in the hard yards, day in and day out. ‚ÄúNice to get back after the injury, I have not taken anything for granted, especially playing for Australia, appreciate every moment of my career,‚Äù he had said.

newsArray.title: ‚ÄòUnseen‚Äô Video of Virat Kohli After Defeat in ICC Cricket World Cup 2023 Final Against Australia Goes Viral
newsArray.description: Virat Kohli scored 765 runs from 11 matches in the ICC Cricket World Cup 2023 and was the highest scorer of the competition. Yet it didn't prove to be enough for India's victory.
newsArray.content: India suffered a heart-breaking loss against Australia in the final of the ICC Cricket World Cup 2023 at the Narendra Modi Stadium in Ahmedabad. Despite having a fantastic campaign with the bat, Virat Kohli couldn't take India to the trophy. In a new, unseen video that got surfaced on social media, Kohli was spotted knocking off the bails of the wicket with his cap in disappointment as the Australian cricketers celebrated their victory. Fans related to his devastation and the video went viral on social media. UNSEEN VIDEO OF KOHLI üíî ‚Äî cricket videos (@RizwanStum60450)

newsArray.title: New Test opener need not be a specialist: Cummins
creator: Scott Bailey
newsArray.description: Australia captain Pat Cummins has said he would have no objection to Australia opting against a specialist opener to replace David Warner.
newsArray.content: Captain Pat Cummins would have no issue with the selectors opting against a specialist opener to replace David Warner in Australia's Test team, indicating picking the best batsman should be a priority. Warner's rollercoaster 112-Test career will come to an end at the SCG this week, with the veteran opener fulfilling his dream of a home farewell when Australia play Pakistan in the third Test. But amid the celebrations for Warner this week in a series that is already won, the biggest question that looms is who will replace him against West Indies in Adelaide on January 17. Marcus Harris, Cameron Bancroft and Matt Renshaw remain the front-runners out of the specialist openers, but Australia are open to going outside that group. Coach Andrew McDonald left the door open earlier this week for Cameron Green to take on the job, if it allowed Australia to pick their best six batsmen. Another option would be to shift Travis Head, Marnus Labuschage or Mitch Marsh to the top, allowing Green to return to the side. The likes of Ricky Ponting and Justin Langer have each warned against such a move, while Bancroft has also voiced a case for a specialist to be selected. But Cummins said he would be open to a move from a regular middle-order batsman. "Uzzy (Usman Khawaja) wasn't a specialist (opener) until it was basically the only spot available in the team and he forced his way in," Cummins, who has been involved in informal discussions on the looming selection, said. "Ideally, you've got someone who's had experience opening, but I don't think it's a blanket rule." Cummins has some first-hand experience on the topic, as a Test quick who has taken the new ball against specialist openers and those filling in the role in opposition teams. "I think every case is different," Cummins said. "If someone's been picked in the side as an opener, but their record's not great, you feel probably feel more of a chance (to get their wicket), rather than if you're picking their best batter. "I don't think it's a big deal. It's just a batting position, everyone chops and changes around a little bit." Cummins on Tuesday lauded Warner as Australia's best-ever three-format batter, and noted his absence will be felt as much off the field as on it. The 37-year-old will play in this year's T20 World Cup, and while he has retired from ODI cricket, Warner is open to a comeback in major 50-over tournaments if asked. Australia's captain indicated that would likely not be required, but was not wholly opposed to the idea of an uncontracted Warner returning. "It's probably time to give some others a crack," Cummins said. "But knowing he is still going to be playing cricket, it might be more of a break-glass-in-case-of-emergency option. "He's going to be scoring runs somewhere in the world, so you never know." Warner's retirement is the first from within the Test team since Mitchell Johnson's in late 2015. But many more loom in coming years with Labuschagne the only player from an unchanged XI for the Sydney Test aged under 30. Cummins is confident, however, the vast majority of the team will be able to face India next summer. "Realistically there is going to be some rate of change," Cummins said. "We probably thought it was going to happen a little bit sooner but everyone is hanging on. "After this block of Test matches, we don't play again until next summer. So I don't see anything in the immediate future that is going to change."

Cummins on Tuesday lauded Warner as Australia's best-ever three-format batter, and noted his absence will be felt as much off the field as on it. The 37-year-old will play in this year's T20 World Cup, and while he has retired from ODI cricket, Warner is open to a comeback in major 50-over tournaments if asked. Australia's captain indicated that would likely not be required, but was not wholly opposed to the idea of an uncontracted Warner returning. "It's probably time to give some others a crack," Cummins said. "But knowing he is still going to be playing cricket, it might be more of a break-glass-in-case-of-emergency option. "He's going to be scoring runs somewhere in the world, so you never know." Warner's retirement is the first from within the Test team since Mitchell Johnson's in late 2015. But many more loom in coming years with Labuschagne the only player from an unchanged XI for the Sydney Test aged under 30. Cummins is confident, however, the vast majority of the team will be able to face India next summer. "Realistically there is going to be some rate of change," Cummins said. "We probably thought it was going to happen a little bit sooner but everyone is hanging on. "After this block of Test matches, we don't play again until next summer. So I don't see anything in the immediate future that is going to change." Australian Associated Press

newsArray.title: Records are meant to be broken: McGrath backs Lyon to top all-time Australia list
newsArray.description: Records are meant to be broken: McGrath backs Lyon to top all-time Australia list
newsArray.content: Listen to Story Legendary Australia fast bowler Glenn McGrath backed off-spinner Nathan Lyon to continue going on a record-breaking spree. to get to 500 Test wickets. The veteran off-spinner achieved the feat during the first Test of the ongoing 3-match series against Pakistan in Perth in December 2023. Glenn McGrath, who will be in Sydney for the Pink Test from January 3, said he was confident that Nathan Lyon would go past his Test tally and he has no problems being overtaken by the veteran off-spinner. Lyon is in the third spot in Australia's all-time Test list with 505 wickets in 124 matches. McGrath had finished his career with 563 wickets in 124 Tests while the late Shane Warne had 708 Test wickets in 145 Tests. Lyon, 36, has shown no signs of slowing down and has been an integral member of the Australian Test side, both overseas and at home. Lyon's ability to trouble opposition batters with his off-spin on pitches in Australia that are not conducive for spin bowling has set him apart from the rest. ‚ÄúTo me, records are there for people to break. If Lyono goes past (me), credit to him. He‚Äôs had an incredible career. I wish him all the best, I hope he goes past me. That‚Äôs what it‚Äôs about," McGrath said in Sydney as his foundation was preparing for the Pink Test, aimed at raising awareness about Breast Cancer and fundraising. "I will still be the most wickets by a fast bowler, so at least I have got something up my sleeve," he added. The former Australian fast bowler did not rule out Nathan Lyon's chances of going past Shane Warn√©'s tally, saying it would be completely up to the off-spinner to decide if he wanted to give that shot. Whether he gets to ‚ÄòShano‚Äô, that might be a different kettle of fish. It is up to him. He is obviously bowling well, he knows the game so well. It is totally up to him," McGrath added. Lyon flaunted his commitment and passion for the game when he made an incredible recovery from a calf injury tha sidelined him for the second-half of the 2023 season. Lyon underwent a rigorous 13-week rehabilitation program to get fit in time for the series against Pakistan. Lyon has often spoken about his desire to prolong his career. After getting to 500, Lyon stressed the importance of not taking anything for granted and putting in the hard yards, day in and day out. ‚ÄúNice to get back after the injury, I have not taken anything for granted, especially playing for Australia, appreciate every moment of my career,‚Äù he had said.

newsArray.title: ‚ÄòUnseen‚Äô Video of Virat Kohli After Defeat in ICC Cricket World Cup 2023 Final Against Australia Goes Viral
newsArray.description: Virat Kohli scored 765 runs from 11 matches in the ICC Cricket World Cup 2023 and was the highest scorer of the competition. Yet it didn't prove to be enough for India's victory.
newsArray.content: India suffered a heart-breaking loss against Australia in the final of the ICC Cricket World Cup 2023 at the Narendra Modi Stadium in Ahmedabad. Despite having a fantastic campaign with the bat, Virat Kohli couldn't take India to the trophy. In a new, unseen video that got surfaced on social media, Kohli was spotted knocking off the bails of the wicket with his cap in disappointment as the Australian cricketers celebrated their victory. Fans related to his devastation and the video went viral on social media. UNSEEN VIDEO OF KOHLI üíî ‚Äî cricket videos (@RizwanStum60450)

newsArray.title: J-Mac earns more cash than Zac during Hong Kong stint
newsArray.description: James McDonald has beaten Zac Purton at his own game.
newsArray.content: Horse Racing Don't miss out on the headlines from Horse Racing. Followed categories will be added to My News. James McDonald has beaten Zac Purton at his own game. In October 2022, Purton famously told J-Mac he was ‚Äústupid‚Äù for staying in Australia and not chasing the riches on offer in Hong Kong. ‚ÄúAt the end of the day when he looks at his bank account and he looks at my bank account, he‚Äôs stupid for staying in Australia,‚Äù Purton told SEN. ‚Ä¢ ‚ÄòWe are humans, my heart bleeds‚Äô: Williams extends hand to Khawaja ‚ÄúHe can stay (in Australia), win all the trophies, get all the accolades, and at the end of his career he‚Äôll still have a mortgage on his home. It‚Äôs as simple as that. Financially it just doesn‚Äôt make sense. ‚ÄúYou can make six to seven times comfortably (in Hong Kong) what he would make a year.‚Äù Well, McDonald has just had a taste of that life, completing a 37-day stint in the Asian racing mecca and pocketing more cash than the six-time Hong Kong champion over the same period. In Hong Kong, a jockey gets 10 per cent of the prizemoney for winning and 5 per cent for finishing second to sixth. McDonald‚Äôs 15 winners earned $HK35,296,800, meaning he trousered a total of $HK3,529,680 ($A664,137), the bulk of which came from Romantic Warrior ‚Äôs brave victory in the Group 1 Hong Kong Cup. Wunderbar caps a J-Mac treble! The star rider returns a three-timer on the final day of his short-term contract... √∞¬ü¬î¬• @mcacajamez #LuckyStart | #HKracing pic.twitter.com/awPyARiFiX ‚Äî HKJC Racing (@HKJC_Racing) January 1, 2024 In that same period, Purton had 19 winners ($HK29,439,600) but only snared himself $HK2,943,960 ($A553,883) because they were in lesser quality races. His Group 1 victory, the Hong Kong Sprint with Lucky Sweynesse , was worth significantly less than the Cup while 12 of the 19 came in Class Four or Class Five. In contrast, 11 of McDonald‚Äôs 15 successes came in Class Three or above. ‚Ä¢ Triumph, scandal and tragedy ‚Äì the moments that shaped 2023 Across 12 meetings from November 26 to January 1, McDonald collected a grand total of $HK50,398,695 in prizemoney, his share a very healthy $HK4,284,774.75 ($A806,140). For the season so far, that $HK50,398,695 number is second only to Purton ($HK92,120,285) and ahead of the likes of Karis Teetan ($HK50,136,960), Vincent Ho ($HK49,963,165) and Hugh Bowman ($HK25,953,550). Not bad for 5¬Ω weeks‚Äô work ‚Äì J-Mac certainly knows what Purton was talking about now. But Purton, as usual, will end up having the last laugh given the maximum tax rate in Hong Kong is 15 per cent while the Australian Taxation Office will take a much bigger bite out of McDonald‚Äôs earnings. Originally published as James McDonald earned more cash than Zac Purton during his Hong Kong stint Join the conversation Add your comment to this story To join the conversation, please log in. Don't have an account? Register Join the conversation, you are commenting as Logout More related stories Horse Racing ‚ÄòWe are humans, my heart bleeds‚Äô: Williams extends hand to Khawaja Melbourne Cup-winning jockey says cricketer Usman Khawaja and any other sportspeople who wish to make a peaceful stand against atrocities in the world deserve understanding. Read more Horse Racing ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs nearly been cyclonic‚Äô: Amazing Magic Millions track forecast It has rained cats and dogs on the Gold Coast but the track curator says don‚Äôt be worried ahead of the new course‚Äôs biggest test on Saturday when Magic Millions dreams go on the line. Read more

newsArray.title: New Test opener need not be a specialist: Cummins
creator: Scott Bailey
newsArray.description: Australia captain Pat Cummins has said he would have no objection to Australia opting against a specialist opener to replace David Warner.
newsArray.content: Captain Pat Cummins would have no issue with the selectors opting against a specialist opener to replace David Warner in Australia's Test team, indicating picking the best batsman should be a priority. Warner's rollercoaster 112-Test career will come to an end at the SCG this week, with the veteran opener fulfilling his dream of a home farewell when Australia play Pakistan in the third Test. But amid the celebrations for Warner this week in a series that is already won, the biggest question that looms is who will replace him against West Indies in Adelaide on January 17. Marcus Harris, Cameron Bancroft and Matt Renshaw remain the front-runners out of the specialist openers, but Australia are open to going outside that group. Coach Andrew McDonald left the door open earlier this week for Cameron Green to take on the job, if it allowed Australia to pick their best six batsmen. Another option would be to shift Travis Head, Marnus Labuschage or Mitch Marsh to the top, allowing Green to return to the side. The likes of Ricky Ponting and Justin Langer have each warned against such a move, while Bancroft has also voiced a case for a specialist to be selected. But Cummins said he would be open to a move from a regular middle-order batsman. "Uzzy (Usman Khawaja) wasn't a specialist (opener) until it was basically the only spot available in the team and he forced his way in," Cummins, who has been involved in informal discussions on the looming selection, said. "Ideally, you've got someone who's had experience opening, but I don't think it's a blanket rule." Cummins has some first-hand experience on the topic, as a Test quick who has taken the new ball against specialist openers and those filling in the role in opposition teams. "I think every case is different," Cummins said. "If someone's been picked in the side as an opener, but their record's not great, you feel probably feel more of a chance (to get their wicket), rather than if you're picking their best batter. "I don't think it's a big deal. It's just a batting position, everyone chops and changes around a little bit." Cummins on Tuesday lauded Warner as Australia's best-ever three-format batter, and noted his absence will be felt as much off the field as on it. The 37-year-old will play in this year's T20 World Cup, and while he has retired from ODI cricket, Warner is open to a comeback in major 50-over tournaments if asked. Australia's captain indicated that would likely not be required, but was not wholly opposed to the idea of an uncontracted Warner returning. "It's probably time to give some others a crack," Cummins said. "But knowing he is still going to be playing cricket, it might be more of a break-glass-in-case-of-emergency option. "He's going to be scoring runs somewhere in the world, so you never know." Warner's retirement is the first from within the Test team since Mitchell Johnson's in late 2015. But many more loom in coming years with Labuschagne the only player from an unchanged XI for the Sydney Test aged under 30. Cummins is confident, however, the vast majority of the team will be able to face India next summer. "Realistically there is going to be some rate of change," Cummins said. "We probably thought it was going to happen a little bit sooner but everyone is hanging on. "After this block of Test matches, we don't play again until next summer. So I don't see anything in the immediate future that is going to change."

So I don't see anything in the immediate future that is going to change." Australian Associated Press
